Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer John Doe, a 4-year-old boy, for further evaluation and management. John sustained superficial partial thickness scald burns to his right buttock and thigh. Initial treatment included debridement and xenografting, followed by autografting.

John has developed early hypervascular scars on the right buttock and thigh. Initially, the scars were managed with PDL for 2 sessions, which were then switched to fCO2 for 3 sessions due to scar maturation. Although combining both PDL and fCO2 lasers has resulted in significant improvement in scar characteristics, ongoing management is required.

I am referring John for a comprehensive assessment of his scar maturation process and to explore additional treatment options to optimize long-term outcomes.

Thank you for your attention to this referral.

Best regards,
Dr. Kelly
referral_content: I am referring John for a comprehensive assessment of his scar maturation process and to explore additional treatment options to optimize long-term outcomes.

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 61-year-old woman, for further evaluation and management. Mrs. Doe has a significant family history of trigeminal neuralgia (TN), with two brothers also afflicted by the condition. Her symptoms include paroxysmal pain triggered by talking, chewing, and light touch of the nasal wing. Recent MRI findings revealed a neurovascular conflict resulting in dislocation and atrophy of the trigeminal root.

Referral Reason: Given the MRI findings and her severe symptomatic profile, I believe Mrs. Doe would benefit from a specialized neurological assessment and potential surgical intervention for her trigeminal neuralgia. The current management is insufficient to control her episodes, and expert input is necessary to determine the best course of treatment.

Thank you for your attention to this referral.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 2-year-old female child from a rural area in the southern region of Ethiopia. The patient presented 18 hours after sustaining a hyena bite to the head and face, resulting in a compound depressed skull fracture with a visible dural tear and oozing of brain tissue, as well as a pre-auricular laceration.

The patient requires specialized care due to the severity of her injuries. Initial treatment involved proper irrigation and debridement, removal of bone fragments, and dura-plasty for a 3 x 2 cm dura defect. She was placed on antibiotics and showed improvement upon discharge. Given the complexity of the injuries, further neurological and reconstructive evaluation is needed to ensure comprehensive recovery and prevent potential complications.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this case.

Best regards,
Dr. Alex Johnson

She was placed on antibiotics and showed improvement upon discharge. Given the complexity of the injuries, further neurological and reconstructive evaluation is needed to ensure comprehensive recovery and prevent potential complications.

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 59-year-old Caucasian woman, to your nephrology practice for further evaluation and management of a recent acute-on-chronic kidney injury.

Mrs. Doe has a history of chronic kidney disease stage 3bA1 of unknown aetiology, irritable bowel syndrome, osteoporosis, controlled hypertension, and hyperthyroidism. Sincerely,

Dr. Smith

Dear Colleague,

Please find below the details of my patient:

A 45-year-old woman, a farmer by profession, presented with a 20 cm x 9 cm plaque on the sole and lateral borders of her right leg. The lesion has a distinct ridge at the periphery and started on her right ankle as a small coin-shaped annular lesion about 15 years ago, gradually spreading to involve the plantar and lateral surfaces of her right foot. She typically works in fields with bare feet. There is no family history of this disease. Based on these observations, the patient has been provisionally diagnosed with giant PK.

Given the complexity and progression of this condition, I am referring her to your specialized care for further evaluation and appropriate management.

Best Regards,
Dr. John Smith
referral_content: Given the complexity and progression of this condition, I am referring her to your specialized care for further evaluation and appropriate management.

I hope this letter finds you well.

I am writing to refer a 11-year-old male patient, John Doe, who presented to us with fever, lower limb swelling, and breathing difficulty for 5 days. On examination, he was febrile, with tachycardia and tachypnea. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral in-hemogeneous nodular opacities with cavitatory consolidation. Venous Doppler showed right popliteal vein thrombosis. Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) revealed septic pulmonary embolism. Child was treated with intravenous antibiotics and subcutaneous low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and other supportive care.

The reason for this referral is to provide further specialized care for septic pulmonary embolism in pediatric patients. Despite our aggressive management, the child unfortunately succumbed to massive acute pulmonary hemorrhage after 2 days in intensive care. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe

She experienced left face/arm clonic seizures spreading to the other side every few minutes and required extensive medical management including lorazepam, phenytoin sodium, levetiracetam, sodium valproate, and clobazam. Thank you for your attention to this referral. Please feel free to contact me if you require any further details.

Best regards,
Dr. John Smith

Dear Colleague,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 58-year-old male, to your esteemed care.

Patient's Details:
Name: John Doe
Age: 58
Gender: Male

The patient presented with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. A CT scan indicated a left hilar lesion, raising suspicion for lung carcinoma. A subsequent whole-body FDG PET/CT scan revealed an FDG avid lesion in the left hilar region, multiple FDG avid metastatic lesions, and an FDG avid lesion involving the left lamina of the thyroid cartilage with an associated soft tissue component. A biopsy of the left hilar mass confirmed the diagnosis of left lung carcinoma.

Given the diagnosis, I believe Mr. Doe requires comprehensive oncological evaluation and management. The presence of metastatic lesions necessitates a systemic treatment approach, and your expertise in oncology would be greatly beneficial for this patient.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Smith

Dr. X, University Hospital of Heraklion 
Heraklion, Crete 

Dear Dr. X, 

I am writing to refer a 19-month-old female patient who presented with a hemicoma as a result of acute obstructive hydrocephalus. According to her parents, she has experienced headaches, often worse in the morning, followed by vomiting, gait disturbance, and seizures. Prior to admission, a funduscopy showed papilledema. Additional prior neurologic examination revealed ataxia, dysmetria, and nystagmus. An MRI has diagnosed a tumor in the posterior fossa, demonstrating variable enhancement with contrast. The haematological and biochemical parameters were within normal limits.

Referral Reason: The patient requires urgent evaluation and potential surgical intervention for the tumor diagnosed in the posterior fossa as it is causing significant neurological compromise and obstructive hydrocephalus. Immediate attention from a pediatric neurosurgeon is advised to prevent further deterioration and to address the underlying cause of her symptoms.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this urgent matter.

Kind regards,

Dr. A
referral_content: The patient requires urgent evaluation and potential surgical intervention for the tumor diagnosed in the posterior fossa as it is causing significant neurological compromise and obstructive hydrocephalus. Immediate attention from a pediatric neurosurgeon is advised to prevent further deterioration and to address the underlying cause of her symptoms.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Ellen Green, an 82-year-old female patient, for further assessment. She was admitted to our hospital following an inferior STEMI accompanied by shock. We initiated an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), and transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) identified a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Emergency VSD repair and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) were performed. Her postoperative course was uneventful, and no residual shunt was detected at follow-up after three years.

The referral is for ongoing cardiac evaluation and management to ensure the long-term stability of her cardiovascular health following significant intervention.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe
referral_content: The referral is for ongoing cardiac evaluation and management to ensure the long-term stability of her cardiovascular health following significant intervention.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to introduce an 8-year-old girl who suffered a grade 2 car-tire injury to her leg. The initial wound appeared clean, and progressive granulation was observed with regular dressing changes. On post-trauma day (PTD) 40, the granulation tissue was excised, and debridement was performed. An artificial dermis, accompanied by a split-thickness skin graft (STSG), was applied to cover the raw surface. During a 5-year follow-up period, no secondary deformity was noted, and the surgical outcome has been excellent.

The reason for this referral is to ensure the continued monitoring and management of the graft site for any potential long-term complications. Given the patient's excellent recovery thus far, I believe ongoing surveillance is critical to maintaining the surgical outcome's integrity.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to ensure the continued monitoring and management of the graft site for any potential long-term complications. Given the patient's excellent recovery thus far, I believe ongoing surveillance is critical to maintaining the surgical outcome's integrity.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 59-year-old male, who initially presented in 2012 with an ulcerated nodule on his right cheek. The nodule had a duration of 6 weeks and measured 3.2 cm, with a central ulcer of 1 cm. CL was confirmed by smear examination. He underwent treatment with 18 doses of weekly intralesional SSG, followed by an additional 18 doses administered every other week due to less than 50% improvement. Despite this extended regimen, the lesion persisted, and repeat smear and culture four months later remained positive for parasites.

The patient requires a specialist consultation for further evaluation and possible alternative treatment options to effectively manage his persistent lesion. Given his unresponsive disease course to intralesional SSG therapy, advanced therapeutic strategies may be necessary.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith

Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer my patient, Mrs. Jane Doe, a 55-year-old woman, for further evaluation and management.

Mrs. Doe presented with an insidious onset of left ocular proptosis of uncertain duration. Her visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Examination demonstrated eyelid retraction with proptosis of the left eye (clinical activity score (CAS) 3). MRI showed enhanced, thickened extraocular muscles, particularly in the inferior and superior recti. Her TSI was 753%, total IgG 1,496 mg/dL, and IgG4 167 mg/dL with an IgG4/IgG ratio of 11.1%.

The referral reason is the noted proptosis of uncertain duration and significant imaging findings suggestive of an underlying inflammatory or infiltrative process. Further specialist input is required to determine the precise diagnosis and appropriate care plan.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dr. John Green
referral_content: The referral reason is the noted proptosis of uncertain duration and significant imaging findings suggestive of an underlying inflammatory or infiltrative process. Further specialist input is required to determine the precise diagnosis and appropriate care plan.

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Smith, a 60-year-old male patient, for further evaluation and management of his chronic migraines with aura. 

Mr. Smith has experienced episodic migraines for the last 5 years. These severe headaches, described as throbbing and rated 10/10 in intensity, typically start in the occiput and spread to the left supraorbital region. The episodes, which occur once per week and last about 10 hours, are accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. His migraines are often triggered by sugar intake, and he averages around 6 hours of sleep per night. Previous abortive treatment with naproxen was unsuccessful, and he is currently on gabapentin for prophylactic management. His most recent brain MRI showed white matter hypertensive changes.

Patient referral is recommended to further investigate his chronic migraine condition and to explore alternative therapeutic strategies.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this referral.

Sincerely,

Dr. Emily Watson
referral_content: Patient referral is recommended to further investigate his chronic migraine condition and to explore alternative therapeutic strategies.

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 45-year-old male, for further management. Mr. Doe has been experiencing diffuse bilateral lower limb pain for the past 8 years and bilateral lower limb weakness for the past 1 year. Recently, he has also developed anterior chest pain upon coughing.

I am referring Mr. John Doe, a 65-year-old male with a history of progressive left knee pain for over five years.

Dear Dr. Smith,

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 19-year-old woman, Ms. Jane Doe, who presented to our clinic with a history of a coin-shaped burn on her right palm. Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 53-year-old male, who recently sustained a 21x17 mm2 full-thickness skin defect on the nasal dorsum following a bicycle accident. Post-accident, the wound was debrided and irrigated; Terudermis was then applied and fixated immediately in the emergency room. The silicone membrane was removed after 14 days, followed by split-thickness skin grafting (STSG) utilizing the epidermal layer of the forehead skin. The patient has rated his scar outcome as 4.0 (good) and reports cosmetic satisfaction.

Referral Reason: Given the extent of the injury and subsequent treatment, I recommend further evaluation by a specialist to assess the need for ongoing dermatological care or potential revisions to optimize cosmetic and functional outcomes.

Dr. Sarah Lee

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, an 18-year-old male, for further evaluation and management following a severe road traffic accident (RTA). His medical history includes a compound fracture in the tibia and patella with a defect involving the knee and the upper one-third of the right leg. Initial treatment included debridement and the application of an external fixator.

Patient Name: John Doe
Age: 18
Gender: Male

On the 2nd post-operative day, a latissimus dorsi (LD) flap and serratus anterior (SA) free flap were performed. Anastomosis was conducted to the lateral genicular artery in a healthy plane posterior to the zone of trauma. The muscles were inset on either side of the anastomosis, enabling complete wound cover.

The referral is for further orthopedic and reconstructive consultation to discuss ongoing rehabilitation and potential long-term outcomes related to the complex injury and surgical interventions performed.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: The referral is for further orthopedic and reconstructive consultation to discuss ongoing rehabilitation and potential long-term outcomes related to the complex injury and surgical interventions performed.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 41-year-old male, who recently experienced subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) in the basal cistern and in the right sylvian fissure, as well as intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in the right frontal lobe. Upon admission, he was classified as Hunt and Hess Grade III (HHG III). Cerebral angiography revealed a 10 x 11 mm aneurysm at the dorsal wall of the right internal carotid artery, and coil embolization was successfully performed. He was discharged without major complications and has been graded as Glasgow Outcome Scale (GO) 5, 21 months post-procedure. He currently is doing well independently.

The referral is being made for a follow-up assessment to ensure the stability of the aneurysm and overall neurological health. Given the history of aneurysmal rupture and subsequent intervention, ongoing monitoring by a specialist is essential to detect any potential issues early.

Sincerely,
Dr. Emily Smith

whole_letter:
Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 65-year-old male patient, who presented to our clinic with a sudden diminution of vision in the right eye for one day. His best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye was 10/200. Clinical examination using slit-lamp evaluation and measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP) was normal.

Fundus examination revealed a submacular hemorrhage (SMH) with a large pigmentary epithelial detachment (PED). Fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed blocked choroidal fluorescence, while indocyanine green angiography (ICG) indicated dye leakage consistent with a subfoveal choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM), confirmed by varying reflectivity on optical coherence tomography (OCT). His left eye was normal.

Given the findings, I am referring Mr. Doe for further evaluation and potential intervention by a retina specialist.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Wilson
referral_content: Given the findings, I am referring Mr. Doe for further evaluation and potential intervention by a retina specialist.

Dear Colleague,

I hope this letter finds you well.

I am writing to refer an 18-year-old male patient who presented with a complaint of amaurosis fugax in his left eye. His initial LogMar vision was 0.2, and fundus examination revealed venous tortuosity and dilation in the central retinal vein. After a month of observation without any particular treatment, his LogMar vision improved to 0.0, and the venous tortuosity and congestion resolved completely.

Referral reason: Despite the full recovery observed after one month, I recommend further ophthalmologic evaluation to rule out any underlying systemic conditions that could have contributed to the initial presentation of central retinal vein changes.

Thank you in advance for your assessment and management of this case.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: Despite the full recovery observed after one month, I recommend further ophthalmologic evaluation to rule out any underlying systemic conditions that could have contributed to the initial presentation of central retinal vein changes.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 77-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis with a kidney transplant, and a 15 pack-year smoking history.

Mr. Doe recently underwent a TEVAR for a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA). Thoracic MRI documented an acute spinal cord injury (SCI), which led to CSFD placement. Within hours of the procedure, his condition improved significantly.

The referral is requested due to his recent acute spinal cord injury and the ensuing neurological deficits. Your assessment and recommendations for further management of his spinal cord injury and any related rehabilitative needs would be greatly valued.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer a patient, a 4-year-old girl named Emily Johnson. Emily is the first child born to nonconsanguineous parents after 39 weeks gestation through cesarean section with no prenatal or neonatal complications.

Emily was recently hospitalized due to intermittent vomiting, fever, and diarrhea. Physical and neurological examinations showed enhanced deep-tendon reflexes and Achilles clonus, though no pathological reflexes were observed. Diagnostic tests, including blood, CSF, urine, and stool analyses did not reveal any infections. Imaging studies, including X-ray, electrocardiogram, and abdominal ultrasound, were normal. However, a mild abnormality was noted on her electroencephalogram (EEG).

The reason for this referral is to seek further evaluation and specialized care for the mild EEG abnormalities observed during her recent hospitalization. Your expertise is sought to identify any underlying neurological conditions and to provide appropriate management plans.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to seek further evaluation and specialized care for the mild EEG abnormalities observed during her recent hospitalization. Your expertise is sought to identify any underlying neurological conditions and to provide appropriate management plans.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring a 21-year-old male patient who initially presented with a 4 mm DM macroperforation at the graft-ost junction during trephination. Immediate deep manual dissection was followed by intracameral air injection and the application of fibrin glue to seal the macroperforation. The graft was then sutured with 16 interrupted 10-0 nylon sutures. Ten days later, the patient experienced DM detachment, which was managed successfully with the injection of 20% sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas, resulting in the DM reattaching and remaining stable.

The patient now requires a specialist's attention to monitor the healing process and ensure there are no further complications related to the initial macroperforation or DM detachment. Your expertise in corneal graft management would be invaluable in ensuring the best possible outcome for the patient.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Doe

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 50-year-old female, for further evaluation and management.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring Ms. Jane Doe, a 37-year-old woman, who has a complex medical history involving chronic sinusitis following her allogeneic bone marrow transplant for idiopathic aplasia a year ago.

Ms. Doe presented with a 5-month history of chronic sinusitis. A CT scan revealed right maxillary sinusitis and left focal basal pneumonia, with cultures from bronchoalveolar fluid identifying Actinomyces spp. She has responded well to right maxillary antrostomy and subsequent high doses of intravenous and oral amoxicillin for 5 months.

Reason for referral: Ms. Doe requires further specialized evaluation and continued management of her chronic sinusitis given her immunocompromised status post-transplant. Your expertise in managing post-transplant infectious complications would greatly benefit her care.

Thank you for your attention to this patient.

Sincerely,

Dr. John Williams
referral_content: Ms. Doe requires further specialized evaluation and continued management of her chronic sinusitis given her immunocompromised status post-transplant. Your expertise in managing post-transplant infectious complications would greatly benefit her care.

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 67-year-old retired gentleman, who has developed an asymptomatic greenish discoloration of the nail plate of his right toe nail over a period of 2 months. Dear Specialist,

Ms. Jane Doe, a 75-year-old female with a history of hypertension, was presented to our department due to dyspnea on exertion. Her blood pressure was 156/74 mm Hg. There were no crackles or murmurs upon auscultation. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm, and a chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly and a large hiatal hernia with air-fluid levels. A two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiogram also indicated a huge extrinsic mass compressing the left atrium, filled with spontaneous echo contrast and internal swirling flow.

We are referring Ms. Doe to your esteemed clinic for further evaluation and management of her large hiatal hernia and potential complications from the extrinsic mass compressing the left atrium. Due to the complexity of her condition, specialized assessment and treatment are necessary to ensure her well-being.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith

Due to the complexity of her condition, specialized assessment and treatment are necessary to ensure her well-being.

Dear Specialist,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer a patient who requires your expert assessment and further management.

Patient Information: The patient is a thirty-three-year-old man diagnosed with hybrid leukemia, further specified as AML. He recently underwent induction chemotherapy, which included intravenously administered vincristine (2mg, weekly), adriamycin (45mg/M2 for 3 days), L-asparaginase (6000 IU/M2 for 12 days), and orally administered prednisolone (60 mg/M2 for four weeks). On the fifth day of treatment, he developed a sudden spiking fever, right lower quadrant pain, and tenderness. A complete blood count revealed a leukocyte count of 700/mm3, composed of 83% lymphocytes, 10% neutrophils, and 7% band forms. Subsequent operation and biopsy results indicated acute gangrenous inflammation and leukemic infiltration of the appendix.

Referral Reason: The patient needs referral for further oncological assessment and management of acute gangrenous appendicitis complicated by leukemic infiltration. Given the complexity of his condition, specialist intervention is crucial to optimize his treatment plan and improve patient outcomes.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Emily Thompson
referral_content: The patient needs referral for further oncological assessment and management of acute gangrenous appendicitis complicated by leukemic infiltration. Given the complexity of his condition, specialist intervention is crucial to optimize his treatment plan and improve patient outcomes.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope this message finds you well.

I am writing to refer my patient, Mr. John Doe, a 73-year-old male, who has developed a significant cervical kyphotic deformity following an isolated ligamentous injury. Despite initial treatment with external immobilization, he progressed to a chin-on-chest deformity with mandibular pressure sores. His condition required posterior surgical stabilization after a successful initial course of traction.

At his 24-month follow-up, Mr. Doe's neck pain had resolved, and X-rays showed satisfactory hardware positioning with preservation of deformity correction.

The reason for this referral is to undertake further assessment and management of any potential long-term complications as well as ensure the continued success of his surgical outcomes.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Foster
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to undertake further assessment and management of any potential long-term complications as well as ensure the continued success of his surgical outcomes.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 24-year-old male patient who sustained a significant heel injury due to a traffic accident. The injury required the transfer of an 18x7 cm ALT-FC flap to cover the defect, which extended to the subcutaneous and muscle layers. The procedure involved using the posterior tibial artery for the recipient vessel and anastomosing the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve with the cutaneous branch of the tibial nerve. The donor site was closed primarily.

The patient needs specialist consultation and follow-up for evaluating the long-term outcomes of the flap transfer and for managing any potential complications. Sixteen months post-surgery, the patient has achieved good soft-tissue coverage and tolerable walking. Patient Information:
Name: John Doe
Age: 13
Gender: Male

John has been experiencing weight loss and abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed an epigastric mass, splenomegaly, and generalized abdominal tenderness. Barium studies indicated remarkable stricture and several filling defects along with mild mucosal thickness in the proximal part of the duodenum. Dr. Jane Smith

Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 47-year-old male patient, to your esteemed care.

Name: John Doe
Age: 47 years
Gender: Male

Mr. Doe underwent a resection of a basal cell carcinoma 1.5 cm in diameter located on his left nasolabial fold. The surgical procedure included a free margin resection of 0.5 cm, followed by reconstruction of the circular skin defect, approximately 2.5 cm in diameter, using a unilateral V-Y advancement flap. Dr. Jane Williams

Role : You are a experienced doctor who have memory of electronic medical records related to many diseases.

    Instruction : please generate one referral letter according to the medical records separeted by ###. It need to be within 150 words.And it should include the very clear referral reason and few simulated patient basic information. The referral reason should be in a whole separate paragraph, which means this paragraph shoule be all about the referral reason. Also the referral reason should be short and precise.You don't use table to contain patient information. If use table, This table should be in the middle part of the letter. Just use different begining and ending information in different letters.The letter begining as well as ending should be short, which means the email and address can be as short as possible. And the it should have simulated information. 

    ###
    A 63-year-old female presented with the chief complaint of a mass lesion on the front of the scalp that occurred 5 years earlier and was diagnosed as basal cell carcinoma in the biopsy. After surgical excision, a skin graft was carried out by harvesting the full thickness of skin from a site. Five days after the surgery, the tie-over dressing was opened and the tie-over dressing, as described previously, was reapplied. The skin graft was well taken without other complications ().
    ###

    output your result in format: {"is_referral_letter": boolean, "is_Papilledema": boolean, "whole_letter": "", "referral_content": "",}

    Rule For is_Papilledema : false.

    Rule For is_referral_letter : if you are producing a referral letter, then it is true.

    Rule For whole_letter : this is the content you generate.

    Rule For referral_content : this content should be a whole paragraph which tells Patient need referral. If the referral_letter contains this content, you should include it. If the letter doesn't contain related information, then it should be null.
whole_letter:
Dear Specialist,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer a patient who requires further evaluation and management.

Name: Jane Doe
Age: 63 years
Gender: Female

Reason for Referral: The patient, Jane Doe, presents with a history of basal cell carcinoma on the front of her scalp, initially diagnosed 5 years ago. After surgical excision and subsequent skin grafting, the patient has had a satisfactory recovery. However, given her history and the potential for recurrence or complications, further specialist evaluation is warranted to ensure comprehensive long-term management.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith
referral_content: The patient, Jane Doe, presents with a history of basal cell carcinoma on the front of her scalp, initially diagnosed 5 years ago. After surgical excision and subsequent skin grafting, the patient has had a satisfactory recovery. However, given her history and the potential for recurrence or complications, further specialist evaluation is warranted to ensure comprehensive long-term management.

    ###
    A 74-year-old woman presented with 3 weeks of stereotyped episodes of tingling and numbness, starting in her right arm and spreading within minutes to contiguous body parts until the face, arm and leg were involved. She had had 5-7 events per day for 3 years. Exam was normal. EEG was normal. MRI showed subcortical hemosiderin deposits on gradient echo sequences (GRE) typical of CAA. whole_letter:
Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring Mrs. Jane Doe, a 74-year-old female, who has presented with a 3-week history of stereotyped episodes of tingling and numbness. These symptoms start in her right arm and spread to contiguous body parts, including her face, arm, and leg. She has experienced 5-7 such events per day for the last 3 years. Her clinical examination and EEG have been normal.

MRI of the brain showed subcortical hemosiderin deposits on gradient echo sequences (GRE), which is typical of Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA). The patient's symptoms have responded well to Topiramate 25 mg taken twice daily, which has successfully terminated the attacks.

The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage her diagnosed Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy and to consider alternate or adjunctive therapeutic strategies.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Alex Brown
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage her diagnosed Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy and to consider alternate or adjunctive therapeutic strategies.

whole_letter:
Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer a patient to your clinic for further evaluation and management. The patient is a 14-year-old Hindu female from an urban background, from a middle socio-economic class, currently studying in class eight.

Following a traumatic event involving an attempted rape by a neighbor, she has been presenting with a range of symptoms including intermittent non-goal directed excitement, rigidity, low-grade fever, posturing, psychological pillow-like symptom, waxy flexibility, mannerism, and verbal stereotypies. After conducting a detailed history, mental state and neurological examination, and relevant investigations, we have provisionally diagnosed her with catatonia in a case of psychosis not otherwise specified (NOS) according to DSM IV criteria.

The reason for referral is to seek your specialized expertise in child psychiatry for further evaluation and management of her complex symptoms. Detailed assessment and treatment planning will be beneficial given the severity and complexity of her presentation.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe
referral_content: The reason for referral is to seek your specialized expertise in child psychiatry for further evaluation and management of her complex symptoms. Detailed assessment and treatment planning will be beneficial given the severity and complexity of her presentation.

To: Oncology Department,

Dear Colleagues,

I am writing to refer a 55-year-old female patient presenting with complex dermatological findings. The patient has an infiltrated, pseudo-vesicular plaque with well defined borders (2 x 1.5 cm) on the proximal region of her left arm. Numerous small erythematous papules are present on the periphery of the lesion. Dermoscopy under polarized light revealed chrysalis, linear-irregular vessels, globules, and milky-red areas. Histopathology indicates nodular Acral Melanocytic Melanoma (AMM) with a Breslow depth of 11.0 mm and Clark level V, along with epidermotropic melanoma metastasis. Additionally, there is a basal cell carcinoma (BCC) located on the frontal region.

The reason for this referral is the need for specialized oncological assessment and treatment planning for advanced melanoma and concurrent BCC. The severity and complexity of the patient's conditions necessitate advanced medical intervention.

Thank you for your assistance.

Kind regards,

[Your Name] [Your Contact Information]
referral_content: The reason for this referral is the need for specialized oncological assessment and treatment planning for advanced melanoma and concurrent BCC. The severity and complexity of the patient's conditions necessitate advanced medical intervention.

Dr. John Smith,
Neurology Department
City Hospital

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 38-year-old woman who presented to our clinic with a headache and difficulty speaking. Initial imaging demonstrated a left frontal subdural hematoma and left temporal venous infarct with a left transverse sinus thrombosis. A hypercoagulable work-up was negative for additional thrombophilias. Ms. Doe was managed initially with intravenous heparin, then transitioned to oral warfarin upon stable follow-up imaging and was discharged home.

The referral reason for Ms. Doe is to ensure continued and specialized neurological follow-up for her excellent recovery post thrombotic event and anticoagulation therapy management. Her recent modified Rankin score was 0, indicating no neurological deficit at the 3-month follow-up, but the rare nature of her condition warrants further specialist evaluation.

Thank you for your attention to this referral.

Sincerely,

Dr. Emily Turner
First Care Clinic
referral_content: The referral reason for Ms. Doe is to ensure continued and specialized neurological follow-up for her excellent recovery post thrombotic event and anticoagulation therapy management. Her recent modified Rankin score was 0, indicating no neurological deficit at the 3-month follow-up, but the rare nature of her condition warrants further specialist evaluation.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 34-year-old male, who has been experiencing intermittent right flank pain for the past 6 months. An initial ultrasound suggested right hydroureteronephrosis with a dilated proximal ureter, though no calculi were found. Further excretory urography confirmed grade 4 hydroureteronephrosis on the right side, with the ureter dilated up to the L4 vertebral level and a tapered segment coursing superiomedially.

Referral Reason: The diagnosis of a circumcaval ureter was suggested. MRU findings further confirmed grade 4 hydronephrosis with the medialized segment of the ureter coursing around the IVC, which necessitates further specialized evaluation and potential surgical management.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Johnson
referral_content: The diagnosis of a circumcaval ureter was suggested. MRU findings further confirmed grade 4 hydronephrosis with the medialized segment of the ureter coursing around the IVC, which necessitates further specialized evaluation and potential surgical management.

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 40-year-old male, for further psychiatric evaluation and management. Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia (ICD-10) for the past two years.

Name: John Doe
Age: 40
Marital Status: Never Married
Education: Completed up to class VII

Dr. Jane Smith

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 67-year-old woman with a history of osteoarthritis (KL grading III) in her right hip. She is 153 cm tall and weighs 54 kg. Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Sally Thompson, a 12-year-old girl, for further evaluation and management. Sally recently underwent a procedure to resect a benign pathologic lesion involving her soft palate. The mucosal defect was reconstructed using a posteriorly based buccinator myomucosal pedicle flap immediately after resection. The flap, which relies on the buccal artery for survival, was closed at the donor site primarily.

The referral is necessary to ensure optimal postoperative care and to monitor the sensory return in the reconstructed area. As this is a neurovascular pedicle flap, regular follow-up would help in assessing the sensory recovery and identifying any potential complications early.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Alex Peterson
referral_content: The referral is necessary to ensure optimal postoperative care and to monitor the sensory return in the reconstructed area. As this is a neurovascular pedicle flap, regular follow-up would help in assessing the sensory recovery and identifying any potential complications early.

whole_letter:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 22-year-old male who presented with vomiting and fever. Initial investigations confirmed Streptococcus Meningitis (SM) by lumbar puncture and blood cultures. SM was successfully treated with antibiotics, and subsequent cerebral MRI identified a pituitary tumor (PT) invading the cavernous sinuses, sphenoid sinus, and brain. Hormonal assessment revealed elevated prolactin (PRL) levels and a gonadotroph deficit. Following the successful sterilization of SM, the PT was treated with dopamine agonists, resulting in normalized PRL levels (25 ng/ml) and a reduction in tumor size. Over a 7-year follow-up, there have been no relapses, even though the sellar floor was not surgically repaired.

The reason for this referral is to seek further specialized endocrine evaluation and management of the patient's persistent gonadotroph deficit, despite successful initial treatment of the PT and SM. Continued expert monitoring is required to ensure no future complications arise.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to seek further specialized endocrine evaluation and management of the patient's persistent gonadotroph deficit, despite successful initial treatment of the PT and SM. Continued expert monitoring is required to ensure no future complications arise.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 60-year-old male, who presented in our department with a unique case. He has a history of cardiac transplantation and has been on immunosuppressive therapy for several years.

Mr. Doe developed a cauliflower-like tumor mass in the perianal region in June 2009. Detailed examination showed no propagation into the anal canal, but the lesion increased in size, causing difficulty in walking and sitting. Consequently, a large surgical excision was performed, and the area was reconstructed using a bilateral rotation S-plasty flap. Although his postoperative course was complicated by an unilateral hematoma and subsequent partial dehiscence of the flap, the wound was managed with daily wound cleansing, resulting in a satisfactory final outcome.

The reason for this referral is to ensure ongoing specialized care and follow-up management. Mr. Doe's complex medical history and recent surgical intervention warrant continued surveillance by a specialist in this field.

Thank you for your attention to this patient.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to ensure ongoing specialized care and follow-up management. Mr. Doe's complex medical history and recent surgical intervention warrant continued surveillance by a specialist in this field.

Dear Dr. Green,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 46-year-old male weighing 68.2 kg, who recently presented with complications following right tibial graft surgery. He underwent this operation to address an oroantral fistula.

Mr. Doe sustained a fracture after jumping from a truck just 20 days post-surgery. Noninvasive reduction and fixation procedures were performed for a duration of 56 days. We are pleased to note that the fracture completely healed after six months.

Despite the successful healing of the fracture, Mr. Doe has been experiencing persistent pain and swelling localized to the site of the previous fracture. We suspect potential complications such as post-surgical infection or delayed bone union.

We kindly request your expert evaluation and management for these ongoing symptoms to prevent any further complications.

Thank you for your attention and cooperation.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith
referral_content: Despite the successful healing of the fracture, Mr. Doe has been experiencing persistent pain and swelling localized to the site of the previous fracture. We suspect potential complications such as post-surgical infection or delayed bone union.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 27-year-old female, to your care for further evaluation and management.

Ms. Doe has experienced persistent Anemia and Leukopenia. Despite initial treatment and follow-up, her Anemia remained refractory, prompting a bone marrow aspiration (BMA) and biopsy (BMB) which revealed criteria consistent with Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS). Additionally, Ms. Doe underwent surgery for a breast mass and was subsequently diagnosed with breast cancer. Following chemotherapy, her Anemia and Cytopenia resolved.

Given her medical history and the resolution of her symptoms post-chemotherapy, a thorough re-evaluation and specialized care are necessary to ensure comprehensive management of her condition.

Thank you for your attention to this case. Please feel free to contact me for any further information.

Sincerely,

Dr. John Smith
referral_content: Given her medical history and the resolution of her symptoms post-chemotherapy, a thorough re-evaluation and specialized care are necessary to ensure comprehensive management of her condition.

Dear Colleague,

I am referring a 38-year-old male patient who has presented with vague epigastric pain. Diagnostic imaging included MRI using axial FIESTA sequences, which indicated superior mesenteric vein (SMV) swirling around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), consistent with midgut volvulus. This finding was corroborated by a plain CT scan. Coronal FIESTA and T2 fat-saturated images highlighted a prominent duodenal loop on the right side of the abdomen and jejunal loops on the right with ileal loops on the left, suggesting malrotation.

The patient requires specialized surgical assessment and possible intervention for midgut volvulus and malrotation.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe
referral_content: The patient requires specialized surgical assessment and possible intervention for midgut volvulus and malrotation.

Dentist, Pediatric Dental Clinic

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer a patient, James Anderson, a 12-year-old boy, who presented with significant pain in the upper anterior tooth. The patient is in good general health.

During the intra-oral examination, we observed a comparatively wider maxillary right central incisor with a deep anatomic pit on the palatal surface. Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 27-year-old male, who has been experiencing progressive hair loss from the scalp over the past 6 months. He also reports itching and a slight burning sensation.

Patient Name: John Doe 
Age: 27 
Gender: Male 

On examination, Mr. Doe presents with well-defined purplish plaques with atrophy of the skin, primarily affecting the vertex and extending to the parietal areas. Trichoscopy revealed perifollicular scales, diminished follicular ostia, and white dots. Additionally, blue-grey dots around the follicular structures appeared as a target pattern. Histopathology is consistent with a diagnosis of Lichen Planopilaris (LPP).

The reason for this referral is further evaluation and management of Lichen Planopilaris (LPP), which has not responded adequately to initial treatment. Your expertise in dermatologic care is highly sought after to devise an appropriate management plan.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is further evaluation and management of Lichen Planopilaris (LPP), which has not responded adequately to initial treatment. Your expertise in dermatologic care is highly sought after to devise an appropriate management plan.
